body: @chavdar @zliu41 @liyinan926 Would you guys have some time to get in IRC today and discuss this?
Can you add markers to all the interfaces (https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/551)
@sahilTakiar can you take look. Thanks.
Will take a look today

One thought I had to solve your possible HDFS performance issues is to detect specific filesystems and handle them differently. For example, if we detect that the filesystem is HDFS we can optimize the publish by performing a rename of the folder and then mark the workunitstates as complete. On the other hand, for any other filesystem we will continue to use the method proposed in this PR.  

What do you think?

To confirm we are talking about `HadoopUtils.movePath`? Doesn't this method already handle this? If the `URI`s are the same then it will just do a `renamePath` (so if its HDFS -> HDFS or local -> local then it just invokes a rename operation which is what we want); and this rename operation can be at a folder. We basically want to avoid renamining each file individually when the data is moving from HDFS -> HDFS or local -> local.

If the file systems are different then it uses `FileUtil.copy` which just walks the tree and uploads each file individually. This is fine, the only optimization we may want to make is to walk the tree ourselves and spawn a new thread for each file upload. I don't think it is possible to atomically bulk upload a bunch of files to HDFS, you would have to bulk upload them to a staging folder and then perform a rename operation.

You are correct that `movePath` correctly handles doing a rename when moving between the same filesystem and a copy/delete when moving between different filesystems.  Also, like you mentioned above, this PR already walks "the tree ourselves and spawn a new thread for each file upload".  It does this by calling `movePath` for each file within the tree.  When the call succeeds it updates the WorkUnitState to complete.  @zliu41 concern is that this will reduce performance for moves within the same filesystem.  My suggestion above was that the publisher detect that the publish is between the same filesystem and that the filesystem is HDFS (not sure what the FileSystem implementation for this is), then optimize the publish by calling `movePath` on each root folder (not walking the directory tree) and when successful update all WorkUnitStates for that path to complete.

Does this make sense?  I'll be away for a bit , but will be back on the computer in about 1.5 hours.  If you would like to discuss this more then, can we do it over IRC: https://webchat.freenode.net/?channels=gobblin

Yes, that sounds good; but if `HadoopUtils.movePath` already does the differentiation between moves on the same `FileSystem` vs. moves on different `FileSystem`s why do we also need to add that distinction in the Publisher.

Can we not simply just say `HadoopUtils.movePath(rootDirectoryPath)` and let the method handle everything.

In this PR, the BaseDataPublisher determines the "moves" needed and uses ParallelRunner to do the work.  `ParallelRunner.movePaths` in turn calls `HadoopUtils.movePath` do the actual move. Due to this, we need to figure out ahead of calling `ParallelRunner.movePaths` the set of moves that can be atomically accomplished.  

One potential issue is that in BaseDataPublisher, there is nothing that ensures that all files are being moved between the same source and destination filesystem.  Additionally, it seems as if a given WorkUnitState can have multiple files associated with it. Before marking the WorkUnitState as complete we need to ensure that all the associated files are moved to their destinations (even if they are different destinations).  All of this seems to really complicate the process.
@eogren The PR is quite large. Any suggestion on the order in which we should read the new classes? A start point? Thanks!

Could we instead have `ParallelRunner.movePaths` return a `List` of `MoveAction`s where a `MoveAction` is a wrapper about the source and destination `Path`, and the `Future` object. Internally the method will create a `MoveAction` for an entire directory if it can commit that entire directory atomically, if it needs to upload each file individually then it creates a `MoveAction` for each file.

This should give the `BaseDataPublisher` enough information to determine when each `WorkUnitState` has been published, right?

Hey @ibuenros - sure, and sorry for the gigantic commit. It was tough to squash it into a bunch of smaller ones.

I would recommend starting with the gobblin-rest-service/ and gobblin-metastore/ changes which are the API changes necessary to power the dashboard.

Next, optionally, is probably gobblin-admin/.../Cli.java to get a sense of some of the queries we may be exposing.

The web files in gobblin-admin/ next - although the web UI is really just making calls to the Gobblin REST server and turning them into tables and fancy graphs.

Last is probably the changes to SchedulerDaemon and the AdminWebServer -- these just start an embedded Jetty server that serves all the web stuff to make it easier for people to get started with the dashboard.

Hope that helps

@sahilTakiar Publishing now happens in two stages.  The first is to group all publish commands (source and destination path) by the source filesystem, source path root, destination filesystem, and destination path root.  Then we walk over the groups.  If the source and destination filesystems are equivalent and the filesystem supports atomically renaming a folder, we rename the source path root to the destination path root.  Otherwise, we run a move for each publish command.

NOTE: each publish command has an associated CommitAction which indicates the number of publishes which must succeed before the WorkUnitState is set to COMPLETE.
@pcadabam can you review?

Overall the approach looks good to me. I have a few comments.
1. Can you extract the persistence and recovery logic into its own class? The writer class seems heavy.
2. How is recovery managed for subclasses of FileAwareInputStreamDataWriter? For example TarArchiveInputStreamDataWriter overrides the write method to extract and write a tar ball file.
3. The Sha computation logic can be moved to static util class/methods

@kadaan can you explain the nature of this PR and why it is necessary? I noticed today that the creation of the `gobblin-dist.tar.gz` is broken. I manually deleted the `gobblin-dist.tar.gz` and when I built the project again a new `gobblin-dist.tar.gz` was not created.

@sahilTakiar When building locally I noticed that the gobblin-dist.tar.gz was not created.  I checked the gobblin/build/gobblin-distribution/distributions folder and noticed that the tarball was there, except it was named: gobblin-distribution-0.6.0-213-gc7ab443.tar.gz.  I changed the code as shown in the PR and the tarball started showing up in the correct location.  I'm not sure what might have changed to cause this to break.

Turns out it has to due to a difference in behavior when running these two commands:

```
./gradlew clean build assemble uploadArchives -PuseHadoop2 -PhadoopVersion=2.6.0 -Dorg.gradle.java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_80.jdk/Contents/Home --info -x test -PpublishToMaven -PartifactRepository=https://...:443/artifactory/libs-release-local -PartifactSnapshotRepository=https://...:443/artifactory/libs-snapshot-local -PdoNotSignArtifacts
```

```
./gradlew clean build -PuseHadoop2 -PhadoopVersion=2.6.0 -Dorg.gradle.java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_80.jdk/Contents/Home --info -x test
```

The first one causes the tarball in gobblin/build/gobblin-distribution/distributions to be named: gobblin-`distribution-0.6.0-198-gba4548f.tar.gz`
The second results in the tarball named: `gobblin-distribution.tar.gz`

I think the code should probably handle both cases.  #617 makes both the `install` and `uploadArchives` targets copy the tarball to gobblin root.
LGTM

Thanks @pcadabam

> On Jan 20, 2016, at 5:14 PM, Chavdar Botev notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> I am sorry for the delay.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

My main concern is that the work unit could get marked as committed by the publisher before it really should be. After looking at this more today, I wonder if this may be more complex then needed. It seems like gobblin has a couple of different ways to handle publishing the data. 

The first is having the job perform the publish. This is similar to the reduce stage in a Map-Reduce program as all tasks must complete and write to staging before any files can be published. This enables jobs (with a couple restrictions) to be created that do not publish any files unless all tasks have completed successfully. The first restriction is that the staging filesystem must support atomic folder renames (HDFS) so that the entire folder will (or will not) be moved from staging to publish. An additional restriction is that when gobblin is run under yarn, the filesystem _must_ be shared with all tasks (HDFS). I believe the current BaseDataPublisher functions correctly with these assumptions. This is the default mode for gobblin. Trying to operate in this mode with the staging folder in S3 causes the problems that were the impetus for this PR.

The second method of publishing is to allow the tasks to publish the files. The original code for this is similar to the generic publish code in this PR (publishing the files indicated in state, rather than the whole folder). This method can result in a subset of the files for the job being successfully published. Therefore it is impossible to perform an all or nothing publish. Additionally, it is not possible to have the publish overwrite the existing data.  That said, this method should be significantly faster as the publish can be distributed and start sooner.  The staging filesystem _does not_ need to be shared among tasks. The filesystem _does not_ need to support atomic folder renames.  This mode is must be explicitly configured for each job.

Does this seem right?

Am I correct in assuming that job level publish was the original system and that task level publish was added afterwards?

Thinking about the use cases for both of these methods leads me to:
1. Job level publish with folder replace is a great fit for loading dimension tables.  If dimension tables were only partially replaced, queries which join against these tables would be "missing" data (due to being dropped out of the join).
2. Task level commit seems to be a great fit for fact tables. Partial data commit will be fixed on subsequent runs. Since data is always being appended there is no risk that while querying the joins will cause "missing" data.  There is a risk for under reported numbers, but that should be fixed with subsequent runs of gobblin.

Does this match how you use this within LinkedIn?

If everything I wrote above hold true, I'm not sure that this PR is providing much benefit. 

I agree that the BaseDataPublisher is doing too much. It would be nice to split up the task and job publish codebases.

Lastly, I see the biggest problem to using gobblin right now as the lack of clear scenarios and the corresponding job files.  gobblin has so many options that figuring out how to accomplish a given task without guidance can be quite difficult.

@sahilTakiar, let me know what you think.
LGTM

@sahilTakiar Thanks for adding the Oozie scheduling.
I also implemented an Oozie integration in a way that
- it uses sharelib to store the gobblin-dist jars
- the workflow and coordinator definitions are generated and copied to HDFS on the fly and the job is submitted  to the Oozie server from code.
  So essentially one only needs to add the scheduling properties to the job configuration and submit it as a gobblin-oozie job.

Would it make sense to contribute these add-ons to the project?

Hey @kadaan,
- Job-Level Publish
  - You are correct that we use this for publishing dimension data
  - Yes the idea is that we want this Publish to be as atomic as possible, as you said, partial reading of dimension data is bad
  - The Job-Level Publish has the advantage that all `Task`s have been completed - this means we know all the (say for a dimension table), is on HDFS, so we can safely publish it using one atomic operation
- Task-Level Publish
  - Yes, this is more useful for fact style data (e.g. the original use case for this was ingesting fact-style data from Kafka)
  - The Task Level Publish basically uses a `SingleTaskDataPublisher extends DataPublisher` - which allows you to publish data one `WorkUnitState` at a time.
  - I don't think the Task-Level Publish has any semantics or guarantees about overwriting data, or publishing data atomically, that is really up to the implementation.

However, as you said there are certain scenarios where you want Job-Level Publishing over Task-Level Publishing. When you want to publish data from multiple Tasks at the same time (usually to the same folder), you want to use the Job-Level Publisher.

Another relevant piece of information, is that Gobblin has a concept of `WorkUnit`s and `Extract`s. An `Extract` is a logical grouping of `WorkUnits` - such as a table in a database, or a partition in Kafka. The goal of the `BaseDataPublisher` was to publish all data from an `Extract` at the same time, atomically. By default, `WorkUnit`s from the same `Extract` end up in the same writer output folder.

I see a few options at this point:
- I still think this PR provides a concrete benefit, because rename operations (atomic or not) can fail, and we shouldn't be marking `WorkUnitState`s as `COMMITTED` until we know for sure the publish was successful.
- If this PR is getting too hectic, it may just be better to implement a new `DataPublisher` that solves the S3 problems.
- A lot of the problems seem to arise from the `ParallelRunner` - we could have a simple version of the `BaseDataPublisher` which does not use the `ParallelRunner`.

As for your last comment, yes there are way too many config options in Gobblin. We have discussed this problem quite a few times within our team and are still working on ways of simplifying the flow. We also want to work on general ease of use for Gobblin. Any suggestions or additional comments you have on this are definitely welcome. I also encourage you to fill out the following Google Form with any suggestions you have: http://goo.gl/forms/LtRRxlxIfp - we are trying to collect more feedback from our users to see what problems they are facing the most.
LGTM with that minor comment

In this case, renames/moves that fail will mark the task as failed. At the moment we are just trying to get our first use case of gobblin into prod and with task publishing we can do that.  Additionally we need to fix an issue with state and duplicate data which is causing state sizes > 300mb.  Once we get this push done, I’ll come back to this PR.

I agree that catching ExecutionException should be moved in the loop. I think that InterruptedException should be handled differently. Typically, that's triggered if the service needs to shutdown. In that case, ParallelRunner.close() should call cancel(true) on the remaining futures..
